body:
I thought Greg Chase was going to make those changes, but yes, I can.

-Chloe

On Thu, May 7, 2015 at 11:49 AM, Roman V Shaposhnik <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @jacksoncvm https://github.com/jacksoncvm thanks for the update! Two
> major points:
> - can you please make sure that Apache Geode is referred to as Apache
>   Geode (incubating) at least for the first time we mention it on the page
>   and definitely on the footers/headers/etc.
> - I still see tons of references to pivotal.io, etc. Can you please
>   fix those links so they point to our ASF infrastructure?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-geode/pull/3#issuecomment-99975911.

What should replace https://network.pivotal.io/products/project-geode (ie.
where are downloads now)? Should we change
https://support.pivotal.io/hc/communities/public/topics/200053218-Pivotal-GemFire-Forum
to something else?  Those are the only 2 pivotal.io links I see...

-Chloe

I basically need someone to set me up and show me how to do this :)

## 

Greg Chase

Director of Product Marketing | Big Data
http://www.pivotal.io/big-data

Pivotal Software
http://www.pivotal.io/

650-215-0477
@GregChase
Blog: http://geekmarketing.biz/
@bobbyhubbard thanks for the PR! I'm merging it as a one-off for now, but please note that we're migrating the website source code into the repo as tracked in PR #3

Hi Vito,
Can you please add unit tests for this pull request?
Done
oops missed publishToMavenLocal task, cancel
Will open different pull request fixing GEODE 222 a different way

Looks good! 
Thanks!
The changes in your last commit look good. But something is odd with this PR, you have some commits from develop that have been cherry picked onto your branch.
Thanks Dan. The branch is cleaned up reverting the cherry-picks.

Thank you for the comments!!

Changes were made via you're recommendations with more to come.

As far as being part of an rpm build I fully agree that this is where the majority of the assumptions that were made came from.

This was made in its current state as more of a helpful template with possibility to grow.

Much more is needed such as distributed execution among nodes and variables to be set at install (ie. setting user).
Changed to info rather than debug.

I've put together a simple set of bash scripts to control a Geode cluster.
It is [yet] missing the process demonization scripts but may be useful as an idea of what could be convenient for Geode cluster control:
https://github.com/sshcherbakov/geode-control

Looks good! I noticed you left in the localProperties and globalProperties fields on PartitionAttributesImpl, as well as leaving the toData/fromData methods alone in that class. Was that to avoid breaking serialization compatibility?
LGTM
+1. I'll go ahead and merge this.
Yes, I was not sure it is safe. I updated it.
Ok, looks good. I will run some tests and merge this.
looks good!

I hit some failures with these changes. I think these related to tests that are using these features that probably need to get fixed.

com.gemstone.gemfire.cache30.CacheXml45DUnitTest.testPartitionedRegionXML
com.gemstone.gemfire.codeAnalysis.AnalyzeSerializablesJUnitTest.testDataSerializables
com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionedRegionCacheXMLExampleDUnitTest.testExampleWithSubRegion
com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionedRegionCreationDUnitTest.testTotalNumberOfBuckets

The AnalyzeSerializables is failing because it detected a change to a serializable class. I think since we are breaking backwards compatibility with older versions of gemfire that's fine, it probably just needs an update to sanctionedSerializables.
Looks good +1
Thanks William - I'll merge it.
Conflicts with PR #38. Withdrawing this version in favor of resubmitting edits reconciled with PR #38.
Sorry, didn't mean to implicate 5 commits and 156 files. Will re-submit.

+1

I'm working on this pull request
Ship it.

A couple of things:
- The MultiAxisChartFX class is GPL code and cannot have an Apache 2.0 license attached to it. This is the reason this code was in a separate repo. A user would need to build that separately and then reference it in this project.
- The readme should be updated. There is no dependency on Geode to build Jvsd.

A number of the pom.xml dependencies removed will need to be re-added as they will be needed for testing (creating stats files...) which at present is missing from this project. So jvsd itself doesn't require geode code itself, the testing code will need it to generate test data and to validate compatibility with geode generated stats files.

The only changes that should be in this pull request for GEODE-341 are the changes specific to this issue. Only the package names should be changed in this pull. The other changes need to be submitted as other issues and pull requests.
Thanks all, I'll close this pull request and start a new one from scratch containing ONLY the package renaming.
Can you remove the Pivotal copyright and add the ASF license header?
created another pull request to address this.
close this one. Will create another one for the same effect
Looks good to me - Thanks!
Thanks @dschneider-pivotal for the review. I have fixed the redundant calls.
this change looks good

Is there are reason why this test should be disabled? I thought our practice is to not disable failing tests?

If you do need to disable the test, please use the @Ignore annotation and provide it a comment explaining why the test is ignored. This lets us easily see a list of ignored tests in jenkins.

+1

On Fri, Dec 18, 2015 at 2:38 PM, Sai Boorlagadda notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @upthewaterspout https://github.com/upthewaterspout Thanks Dan for
> suggesting @Ignore https://github.com/Ignore.
> 
> This test currently failed only once on Geode_develop_UnitTests job but
> consistently failing on GemFire_develop_Sonar.
> So disabling it until it is fixed so that code coverage analysis is not
> impacted.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-geode/pull/62#issuecomment-165912911
> .
I'll go ahead and pull in these changes to test and commit.
This change looks good and the modified unit test still passes
I'll pull this in to commit it.
The changes look good, I will pull them to my local repo and do a final review.  I expect to push them tomorrow if everything is as expected.
Great Vince, thanks.
The changes have been pushed to the Apache repo.
Reviewing the changes. The main issues might be the inclusion in the build process the cloning and building of the MultiAxisChartFX as the gpl license may be problematic.

Hey Vince,
Thanks for reviewing the pull request.
I knew about the license problem regarding project MultiAxisChartFX but we'll need to create a new JIRA to address this, instead of reimplementing the logic within GEODE-342, don't you think?. We could start doing that once the build process is standardized through gradle. Please let me know.
Cheers.
+1 - I'll merge this fix.

It looks like the integration tests are still failing. We should either fix those or mark them as `Ignore`. If the selenium tests (which require a local browser) can be made to work, then consider introducing a new test category; something like `UITest` or `ManualTest`.
This is GEODE-393. I discussed this with Shreedhar, these changes need some tests and then they should be good to merge. I'll pick this up.

LGTM!

+1
this fix needs a dependency in gemfire-core. Will not use this fix.

Hi Ken,
This pull request has a lot of other commits. Can you please close this and open another pull request by following the instructions here https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Code+contributions
Looks like my fork wasn't clean when I created the PR. Closing this one, will open a new one when I get things clean.
To avoid confusion, do not rename the properties file copied from gemfire-core

Looks good! One minor point - I think this is missing something that will tell gradle what the copyPulsePropFile  task depends on. You could either add a dependsOn to the task, or maybe add an inputs.dir to the task:

inputs.dir project(':gemfire-core').sourceSets.main.output

Try running 
/gradlew  gemfire-pulse:copyPulsePropFile
or
/gradlew  gemfire-pulse:war

and you'll see what I mean; it won't generate the original properties file.
Good point. Will create another pull request for this
I reviewed the test and it looks good. I'll pull it in.

You changed these to be ./gradle. I don't think that makes sense. Either someone is using the gradle wrapper - './gradlew' - or they are using in installed copy of gradle, in which case they would do 'gradle" (no ./)

Dockerfile is script, and it starts by clone the repo. So ./gradlew is the appropriate thing do there.

I do wonder how many people will use the source distro vs. just cloning the repo from github. For most people, ./gradlew is the easiest and correct thing to do.

You're correct. I should have changed "./gradlew" to just "gradle" for the .txt and .md files I updated. I also agree that gradlew, not gradle, is the correct usage in Dockerfile.

The problem here with using gradlew is that it's not part of the release distributions. As part of the source distro we shouldn't be calling out a script that's not part of the package. I realize that this conflicts with the  common usage when building from a clone of the github repo. Any suggestion for handling this disconnect between building from source distro vs. repo clone? I favor making the text  instructions consistent with the release.

Should we go back to Anthony's suggestion in GEODE-826 to use the gradlew script from bigtop which I understand could be included in the GEODE source distro.
Review board link -> https://reviews.apache.org/r/42884/

I'm closing this PR in favor of looking at the longer term solution of gradlew vs. gradle in the release distros. The secondary problem I found (path error in README.md) will be dealt with separately.
RBT URL: https://reviews.apache.org/r/43155/
I will pull this in
RBT url: https://reviews.apache.org/r/43345/

Looks like these {@linkplain } links are causing javadoc warns when this is merged to the latest develop:

./gradlew gemfire-core:javadoc

/home/dsmith/data/work/gemfire/open/gemfire-core/src/main/java/com/gemstone/gemfire/cache/operations/OperationContext.java:492: warning - Tag @link: missing '#': "getOperationCode()"

Kirk & Dan,
Thanks for trying, guys. I'll revisit & revise.
Dave

BTW - I can push this change myself, I just thought it would be easier to review as a PR than a reviewboard request. If I get a couple of +1s and no -1s in the next day or so I'll push it.
+1 Awesome!
